item.title: Hello world!
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Welcome to WordPress. This is your first post. Edit or delete it, then start writing!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Hi, this is a comment. To get started with moderating, editing, and deleting comments, please visit the Comments screen in the dashboard. Commenter avatars come from Gravatar.

item.title: Sample Page
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This is an example page. It's different from a blog post because it will stay in one place and will show up in your site navigation (in most themes). Most people start with an About page that introduces them to potential site visitors. It might say something like this:
Hi there! I'm a bike messenger by day, aspiring actor by night, and this is my website. I live in Los Angeles, have a great dog named Jack, and I like piña coladas. (And gettin' caught in the rain.)
...or something like this:
The XYZ Doohickey Company was founded in 1971, and has been providing quality doohickeys to the public ever since. Located in Gotham City, XYZ employs over 2,000 people and does all kinds of awesome things for the Gotham community.
As a new WordPress user, you should go to your dashboard to delete this page and create new pages for your content. Have fun!

item.title: Contact
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Prof Michael Rosemann Executive Director Corporate Engagement Queensland University of Technology Contact us, if you are interested
  • in participating in our NESTT courses, either as a participant in our open enrollment course or if you are interested in organising an in-house event
  • in becoming a delivery partner for the NESTT, in Australia or globally
  • in conducting a NESTT redesign initiative within your organisation
  • in conducting research in the area of rapid redesign approaches
Email: nestt@qut.edu.au

item.title: Philosophy
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: The NESTT is a rapid, people and outcome centred approach to process redesign. NESTT is focused on creating exciting future processes that make today’s processes obsolete. This is achieved by an opportunity-driven mindset and ideation techniques that help participants to explore what is possible instead of just fixing what is broken. However, the NESTT is also dedicated to the often urgent and pragmatic demands of resolving immediate problems along a process (e.g., waste, variation). As such, the NESTT is an ambidextrous approach, i.e. it is dedicated to exploiting and improving current processes as much as to exploring entire new process design opportunities. The actual methodology puts the participating stakeholders at its core and acknowledges that the active, stimulating engagement of all involved parties is one of the most essential success factors.

item.title: Methodology
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
The NESTT approach consists of three stages:
  • THE DESIGN STAGE during which the strategic context, the project aims and the underlying challenge are articulated. The team is formed and all relevant logistical activities are planned.
  • THE INNOVATION STAGE is the core of the NESTT (below) & consists of a range of methods facilitating divergent and convergent thinking.
  • THE TRANSITION STAGE takes the NESTT outcomes into action and utilises contemporary change management approaches.
At the core of the NESTT is a unique, four-week innovation approach with the following four stages (one week each):
  • Navigate the process environment: What is the vision of the process? What are possible process design pathways? What is the current process? What are pain and opportunity points along the process? What are the restrictive policies and procedures? What systems, stakeholders and documents are involved?
  • Expand the mindset: What are possible future processes? What can we learn from engaging approaches such as acting out the process? What process improvement patterns are applicable? What can we learn from other industries? What are under-utilised assets in the context of this process? How can design thinking help to further improve the process? Who are the idea champions?
  • Strengthen the ideas: What do potential users think about the ideas? Are these desired solutions? What needs to be done to make them feasible ideas? What are the underlying technology and policy requirements? What is the risk of each idea and how can any risk identified be mitigated?
  • Tune and Take-off: What makes each idea a viable idea, i.e. what is the business case? What are the interrelationships between the ideas? What are the proposed implementation activities? How do we best pitch the idea to our senior executives?

item.title: Space
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: A unique feature of the NESTT is the way it utilises space. A dedicated room is setup to capture on each of the four walls a specific view on the process to be improved (see diagram). The room has no table and participants will move depending on the methodology between these walls exploring in highly interactive ways alternative design opportunities. The NESTT space is also divided into two halves. The half facing THE NOW wall is the space where pain relief occurs. Here the team will conduct root cause analyses of identified pain points such as waste, variation, bottlenecks, etc. This work is largely reactive and analytical. The half facing THE FUTURE wall is the space where an opportunity-driven mindset dominates. Instead of ‘why is it broken’ the focus is on ‘what else is possible’. Innovate ideation techniques grounded in QUT’s systemic ideation approach are used to derive entire new process solutions that go far beyond the immediate resolution of identified pain points.

item.title: Blog
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: Insights about specific features of the NESTT, case studies, testimonials of organisations as well as individuals that have participated in the NESTT program.

item.title: PUT TOMORROW BEFORE TODAY
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: The NESTT always starts with tomorrow. This is in sharp contrast to the majority of redesign projects. The typical re-design approach is to model today’s process to a sufficient level of detail before identifying pain points along the process using approaches such as lean management, six sigma or the theory of constraints. This approach is well documented in various process lifecycle models and a plethora of tools and methods nowadays exists for the modeling and analysis of business processes. However, this well-defined methodology also comes with a number of shortcomings. First of all, it is an approach reactive to identified pain points. As such the design space is constrained to improvement ideas triggered by internal shortcomings. Second, the resulting improvement ideas tend to be incremental as they focus on the elimination of pain as opposed to capitalising on entire new design opportunities. Third, the stakeholders involved have typically limited guidance on how to come up with better practices making it a methodology highly dependent on the individuals involved. Fourth, finally, and for the reasons above, fixing pain is not really exciting for anyone. These are the main reasons why we put the classical process lifecycle model in the NESTT on its head. Instead of unpacking today, the NESTT starts with shaping tomorrow. Instead of understanding and analysing current issues first, the NESTT’s initial focus in on how tomorrow could look like. And instead of investing the bulk of the intellectual energy on how to overcome current problems, the core intellectual challenge in the NESTT is ‘how do we best get to the desired tomorrow?’. The very first steps in the innovation stage of the NESTT methodology are dedicated to crafting a desired future process that makes current practices obsolete. Thus, the first two days of the innovation work are only occurring on the Future wall when the team explores possible process design alternatives in the three timeframes – 20 days, 20 months, 2020. This work is unconstrained by the current process allowing divergent thinking and considering a comprehensive design space. Our NESTT case studies so far clearly show that such work is a tremendous uplift for the corps spirit of the NESTT team. It is exciting to see how stakeholders build on each others’ ideas, continuously ask themselves what else is possible and develop a shared ambition to make this future process design a reality. The next days and weeks of the NESTT are then dedicated to working out how to best get to these ideas. This re-sequenced lifecycle model tends to lead to much more ambitious process designs, more substantial transformations and overall also to higher levels of motivation within the team as opposed to the traditional reactive pain relief activities. Starting with tomorrow, however, does not come without challenges. Unlike today, tomorrow is far less tangible and it requires strong design and foresight capabilities. Thus, the role of the facilitator will be more influential than in the more predictive process analysis initiatives. In particular, strong story telling capabilities and insights into so-called megatrends (e.g., demographic changes, technology developments) are needed. Nevertheless, organisations able to source such facilitation talent will find the future-driven approach to process re-design rewarding as it unlocks entire new design spaces and much needed energy and motivation within everyone involved.

item.title: THE POWER OF DESIGN PRINCIPLES
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: An essential feature of the NESTT is that its work is led by design principles. Instead of reflecting on the idiosyncratic nature of a specific issue, a design principle is an ideation accelerator, an endorsed point of reference providing default solutions. For example, the endorsed principle ‘One-process’ will provide a direction when a NESTT team uncovers that the same process has been implemented in different ways in different business units. Following this principle will mean that the default will be a common process unless strong arguments justify an individualised process. A design principle can come in two forms: 1) A mandated design principle needs to be implemented. For example, a mandated ‘One-process’ principle will not tolerate multiple process variants. 2) A recommended design principle provides only a suggestion. For example, a recommended ‘No rework’ principle will motivate the NESTT team to eliminate rework steps where ever they can. However, there might be exceptions where rework is still a valid design option. Design principles need to be discussed far before the actual NESTT process starts. It is important to reflect on the design rationale behind each principle to have a shared understanding of the reasons why the principle has been proposed. In the following, I present three selected design principles and their rationale. Make decision rules explicit. Approvals are a common roadblock in many business processes. They require the attention of an expensive supervisor, create non-value adding waiting time and are a sign of being controlled. At the core of an approval is the assessment of a request in light of decision rules by an authorised individual. A main design feature of an approval step is that it is a reliable activity, i.e. the outcome of the approval step should not depend on the individual stakeholder making the decision. Emerging solutions related to robotic process automation target such approval steps. From the view of the person submitting the request, an approval step and its outcome should never be a surprise. The more the requestor knows about the underlying decision rules the lower will be the volume of requests that are to be declined. A declined request reflects, besides the disappointment of the requestor, wasted time in submitting the request. Making decision rules explicit means they are considered when writing the request. As a consequence, the outcomes of the approval process are not a surprise to the requestor and requests with a limited chance for approval are not submitted in the first place. Evidence over confidence. Following the ambition to make decisions as reliable as possible, a request to seek evidence as opposed to relying on the confidence of the decision maker is an important design principle. This principle encourages the NESTT team to be determined to seek sound data as a foundation for relevant decision points. The more a decision is grounded in actual data, the more it will become a reliable decision and ultimately the higher will be the opportunity to automate this decision. Make decisions as late as possible. In his book ‘The Last lecture’ Randy Pausch related to a principle his father has taught him, i.e. making decisions as late as possible. Delaying decisions to a later stage of a process allows improving the quality of a decision by capturing more data and by reducing uncertainty. This principle can be well applied to decision-intensive processes. The application of the principle requires a consideration in terms of when a decision needs to be made. The application of this principle is very common in distribution logistics and known as postponement. For example, preference is given to the delivery of a distribution centre as opposed to an early distribution to regional centres when the actual demand is uncertain. Another well-known example of postponement is the delaying of the coloring of clothes in relevant manufacturing processes as it allows to be more adaptive to fast changing fashion trends. centre as opposed to an early distribution to regional centres when the actual demand is uncertain. Another well-known example of postponement is the delaying of the coloring of clothes in relevant manufacturing processes as it allows to be more adaptive to fast changing fashion trends.

item.title: Course
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
A three day, highly interactive course will take you through the NESTT philosophy and methodology. You will learn how to best utilise the NESTT space and how to become a successful NESTT facilitator. The third day is dedicated to a NESTT simulation during which you will conduct all essential NESTT approaches using a real life case study. Details: https://www.qut.edu.au/study/short-courses-and-professional-development/ short-courses/rapid-process-redesign-nestt
TESTIMONIALS "This thought provoking course really does challenge you to think innovatively. It gives you the practical tools to engage staff, implement ideas and rapidly make a real difference to your organisation's performance." MANAGER, BUSINESS PROCESS MANAGEMENT OFFICE, UNIVERSITY OF AUCKLAND

item.title: References
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded: This 3 minute video provides you with an overview about the four stages of the NESTT. This article is a more detailed summary of the NESTT methodology. It will be published in the upcoming ‘BPM Case Study’ book by Jan vom Brocke and Jan Mendling, Springer (2017).
